docs.lead_paragraph: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan is known for affability and an adherence to Rome’s conservative line.

headline.seo: Timothy M. Dolan of Milwaukee, a Genial Archbishop for New York
headline.main: A Genial Conservative for New York’s Archdiocese
headline.print_headline: A Genial Conservative for the Archdiocese
headline.content_kicker: Man in the News | Timothy Michael Dolan

docs.snippet: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan is known for affability and an adherence to Rome’s conservative line.

docs.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE -- For a few deeply unpleasant days, the Rev. David Cooper found himself in the crosshairs of the Roman Catholic hierarchy. It was 2003, and the priest had opined to a reporter that women should be ordained. Faraway bishops rumbled about censure. Then he picked up the telephone and heard the baritone of Milwaukee's archbishop, Timothy M. Dolan. Father Cooper immediately offered to resign.

headline.main: A Genial Conservative for the Archdiocese
headline.kicker: MAN IN THE NEWS | TIMOTHY MICHAEL DOLAN

docs.abstract: Profile of Archbishop Timothy Michael Dolan, named by Pope Benedict XVI to lead Archdiocese of New York; 59-year-old Dolan is archbishop of Milwaukee; is known as genial man with taste for baseball and beer; in sharp contrast with Cardinal Edward Egan, whom he will replace, he is highly regarded by Catholic reformers for transparency of his archdiocese's finances and takes pleasure in socializing with priests; is from conservative wing of church, which has grown more assertive during past decade; is pragmatic, however, and has not joined archibishops who barred politicians who favor abortion rights from taking communion, nor has he moved to ferret out liberals; career highlights; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan is known for affability and an adherence to Rome’s conservative line.
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: During the stimulus debate, President Obama made several overtures to the Republicans, hoping to bring them on board with his plan, to little avail. Not one House Republican voted for the package, and only three moderate Republicans voted with the Democrats in the Senate.
docs.abstract: Only three Republicans in Congress supported the stimulus plan, despite President Obama's overtures. Should he give up on bipartisanship?
docs.snippet: Only three Republicans in Congress supported the stimulus plan, despite President Obama's overtures. Should he give up on bipartisanship?
